#Text=TO JOHN
#Text=BLAND
#Text=My Lamb , you are so very small , You have not learned to read at all .
#Text=Yet never a printed book withstands The urgence of your dimpled hands .
#Text=So , though this book is for yourself , Let mother keep it on the shelf Till you can read .
#Text=O days that Pass , That day will come too soon , alas !
#Text=CONTENTS
#Text=1. Beautiful
#Text=As the Day 2 .
#Text=Golden Guineas 3 .
#Text=Being Wanted 4 .
#Text=Wings 5 .
#Text=No Wings 6 .
#Text=A Castle and No Dinner 7 .
#Text=A Siege and Bed 8 .
#Text=Bigger Than the Baker 's Boy 9 .
#Text=Grown Up 10 .
#Text=Scalps 11 .
#Text=The Last Wish
#Text=CHAPTER 1 BEAUTIFUL AS THE DAY

#Text=The house was three miles from the station , but before the dusty hired fly had rattled along for five minutes the children began to put their heads out of the carriage window and to say , ' Are n't we nearly there ? '
#Text=And every time they passed a house , which was not very often , they all said , ' Oh , is THIS it ? '
#Text=But it never was , till they reached the very top of the hill , just past the chalk-quarry and before you come to the gravel-pit .
#Text=And then there was a white house with a green garden and an orchard beyond , and mother said , ' Here we are ! '
#Text='
#Text=How white the house is , ' said Robert .
#Text='
#Text=And look at the roses , ' said Anthea .
#Text='
#Text=And the plums , ' said Jane .
#Text='
#Text=It is rather decent , ' Cyril admitted .
#Text=The Baby said , ' Wanty go walky ' ; and the fly stopped with a last rattle and jolt .
#Text=Everyone got its legs kicked or its feet trodden on in the scramble to get out of the carriage that very minute , but no one seemed to mind .

#Text=Mother , curiously enough , was in no hurry to get out ; and even when she had come down slowly and by the step , and with no jump at all , she seemed to wish to see the boxes carried in , and even to pay the driver , instead of joining in that first glorious rush round the garden and the orchard and the thorny , thistly , briery , brambly wilderness beyond the broken gate and the dry fountain at the side of the house .
#Text=But the children were wiser , for once .

#Text=It was not really a pretty house at all ; it was quite ordinary , and mother thought it was rather inconvenient , and was quite annoyed at there being no shelves , to speak of , and hardly a cupboard in the place .
#Text=Father used to say that the ironwork on the roof and coping was like an architect 's nightmare .

#Text=But the house was deep in the country , with no other house in sight , and the children had been in London for two years , without so much as once going to the seaside even for a day by an excursion train , and so the White House seemed to them a sort of Fairy Palace set down in an Earthly Paradise .
#Text=For London is like prison for children , especially if their relations are not rich .

#Text=Of course there are the shops and the theatres , and Maskelyne and Cook 's , and things , but if your people are rather poor you do n't get taken to the theatres , and you ca n't buy things out of the shops ; and London has none of those nice things that children may play with without hurting the things or themselves - such as trees and sand and woods and waters .
#Text=And nearly everything in London is the wrong sort of shape - all straight lines and flat streets , instead of being all sorts of odd shapes , like things are in the country .
#Text=Trees are all different , as you know , and I am sure some tiresome person must have told you that there are no two blades of grass exactly alike .
#Text=But in streets , where the blades of grass do n't grow , everything is like everything else .
#Text=This is why so many children who live in towns are so extremely naughty .
#Text=They do not know what is the matter with them , and no more do their fathers and mothers , aunts , uncles , cousins , tutors , governesses , and nurses ; but I know .
#Text=And so do you now .
#Text=Children in the country are naughty sometimes , too , but that is for quite different reasons .
#Text=The children had explored the gardens and the outhouses thoroughly before they were caught and cleaned for tea , and they saw quite well that they were certain to be happy at the White House .

#Text=They thought so from the first moment , but when they found the back of the house covered with jasmine , and in white flower , and smelling like a bottle of the most expensive scent that is ever given for a birthday present ; and when they had seen the lawn , all green and smooth , and quite different from the brown grass in the gardens at Camden Town ; and when they had found the stable with a loft over it and some old hay still left , they were almost certain ; and when Robert had found the broken swing and tumbled out of it and got a lump on his head the size of an egg , and Cyril had nipped his finger in the door of a hutch that seemed made to keep rabbits in , if you ever had any , they had no longer any doubts whatever .
#Text=The best part of it all was that there were no rules about not going to places and not doing things .
#Text=In London almost everything is labelled '
#Text=You must n't touch , ' and though the label is invisible , it 's just as bad , because you know it 's there , or if you do n't you jolly soon get told .
